candidates.description: John Lennon, Paul McCartney, George Harrison, and Richard "Ringo Starr" Starkey are The Beatles. The hottest band out of Liverpool and kings of the Mersey Beat. Do they have what it takes to make it in America?

Brian Epstein is the manager of both The Beatles and Gerry and The Pacemakers. As manager he is responsible for The Beatles signature suited style and has helped them go from playing dingy nightclubs to selling out shows in their hometown. Can he help The Beatles break into America?

questions.description: Feb. 9, 1964: You are about to play televised for millions of Americans on The Ed Sullivan Show. Your opening song will leave a lasting impression on people, which song do you choose to start with?

answers.description: I Want To Hold Your Hand
answers.feedback: You open with the upbeat classic, I Want To Hold Your Hand. It goes quite well and the audience seems thrilled. After the show you hear some members of the audience arguing if the chorus to the song was I cant hide or I get high. Hopefully this doesnt get you into any trouble.

answers.description: All My Loving
answers.feedback: All My Loving is the perfect introduction to The Beatles for America. It isnt your strongest song but it leaves the audience wanting more. America has met The Beatles!

answers.description: Misery
answers.feedback: Well boys, Im not sure if starting off your set with a slow tune literally titled Misery was the best choice. Lets see if we can salvage this during the second set, yeah?

answers.description: Boys
answers.feedback: Debuting in America with a cover of The Shirelles that Ringo sings is an interesting choice. Daringly youve opted NOT to reverse the genders of the song, leaving conservative America outraged by the homosexual undertones.

questions.description: What do you have to say about your manager, Brian Epstein?

answers.description: PAUL: Hes the fifth Beatle. Hes been instrumental in allowing us to play all around this great country.
answers.feedback: Thanks for the acknowledgement Paul, this is a good likeable answer.

answers.description: JOHN: He makes sure were all being good little Beatles.
answers.feedback: This answer is sure to help fears that The Beatles are corrupting Americas youth.

questions.description: How did you ever decide on a name like The Beatles for the group?

answers.description: JOHN: "Well, I had a vision when I was twelve. And I saw a man on a flaming pie, and he said, 'You are Beatles with an A.' And we are."
answers.feedback: John, what are you talking about? Beatniks may like this but this isnt doing us any favours with the general public.

answers.description: PAUL: We were all huge fans of Buddy Holly and The Crickets and we decided to pay tribute to him.
answers.feedback: This is a solid answer that is sure to boost your popularity in regions where Buddy Holly is still popular.

answers.description: GEORGE: We were all taking too many Bennies in Hamburg and started seeing beetles everywhere.
answers.feedback: George, America doesnt need to know about your past popping pills in Hamburg nightclubs! Were going to have to do some damage control.

questions.description: Do you guys think of yourselves as singers and romantic idols at the same time?

answers.description: JOHN: "We're just singers, you know. Or shouters, whatever you like to call it."
answers.feedback: This is a humble answer that will appeal to the general public.

answers.description: PAUL: Well depends, I guess John and I are singers and Ringo and George are more idle.
answers.feedback: Not a good look disparaging your bandmates. People will think The Beatles lack unity.

answers.description: RINGO: I think of myself as more of a drummer and romantic idol.
answers.feedback: This is the humorous kind of answer that the press expects from a Beatle.

questions.description: What about this rumor that John is leaving the group?

answers.description: JOHN: "It's just a rumour. I dunno how it started. You know, it's just untrue."
answers.feedback: Good job putting the rumours to rest. Faith in The Beatles should increase.

answers.description: PAUL: Not true at all, Im actually the one thats leaving The Beatles
answers.feedback: Not everyone gets your sense of humour, Paul. Some people seem to think The Beatles are disbanding.

answers.description: GEORGE: Yes, John has decided to become a house husband and look after his dear wife and son.
answers.feedback: Even though George intended it as a joke, the public isnt widely aware that John is married yet. This hurts The Beatles image as available young men.

questions.description: You really got started, I understand you particularly John, with a skiffle group. Did this automatically grow into what is now the Beatles, or did this come over a period of quite a number of years?

answers.description: JOHN: You forget, you know. I know I met Paul first, and he sort of joined this little group I had. And then George, you know, and gradually changed-- but it was just us three.
answers.feedback: A succinct answer. The kind that fuels the legend of The Beatles.

answers.description: PAUL: We were actually born as The Beatles, not many people know this but we all came from the same mother. Mother Beatle we called her.
answers.feedback: This is a funny answer that appeals to the youth of America.

answers.description: RINGO: Skiffle? No, we started by playing Beethoven. But we were so bad at it that we ended up with this racket.
answers.feedback: Although intended as a joke, it seems the conservative population has taken it at face value. They approve of this straight laced reference to real music.

questions.description: Some good, Christian Americans are worried that more teenagers are listening to The Beatles than to the words of Jesus Christ. What do you think about that?

answers.description: JOHN: I would say theyre right, we are probably more popular than Jesus.
answers.feedback: John! This is America were talking about. You cant go around saying things like this, people are going to be very upset.

answers.description: PAUL: This whole Beatles thing is just a fad anyway.
answers.feedback: This is a humble answer that skillfully dodges the question. You might have a future in politics Paul.

questions.description: Apr. 23, 1964: After this long on the tour, youre getting tired of playing the same songs every night to a screaming audience who can barely hear anything. Youve decided to introduce a new song into the setlist. Which song do you choose?

answers.description: Roll Over Beethoven
answers.feedback: Although this Chuck Berry cover wins you points with the younger audience, it upsets older conservatives. But who cares about them, right?

answers.description: I Wanna Be Your Man
answers.feedback: Although this song is a Lennon-McCartney original, it is currently in the charts due to a cover by The Rolling Stones. You accidentally raise their popularity as a result.

answers.description: Cant Buy Me Love
answers.feedback: A raucous original like Cant Buy Me Love is the perfect choice to add to your set.

answers.description: Long Tall Sally
answers.feedback: Long Tall Sally is a solid choice to add to your set. However you may want to choose a song that isnt a cover in the future.

questions.description: Some fans have been throwing jellybeans at you before shows, do you think some of the kids should be ejected by the police?

answers.description: GEORGE: "No! Thats stupid, you know. They should just confiscate the jellybeans at the gate."
answers.feedback: A sensible answer that offends no one.

answers.description: RINGO: They should be arrested and persecuted to the highest extent of the law.
answers.feedback: That answer is a little extreme. But it will definitely win you points with older conservatives. But theyre not exactly The Beatles audience.

answers.description: PAUL: I just wish they would throw something else like some pills or something.
answers.feedback: What are you talking about Paul? An answer like this is sure to damage The Beatles reputation.

questions.description: Aug 28, 1964: After a show youre back to your hotel. When you all finally get settled in you get a message from Brian. It seems that Bob Dylan is here to visit you! As huge Bob Dylan fans you are all quite excited. After a brief introduction he asks if The Beatles would be interested in smoking some marijuanna. What do you do?

answers.description: Light up with Bobby
answers.feedback: Any awkwardness in the room vanishes as you four and Bob spend the next hour pranking reception and trying to find some food.

answers.description: The Beatles arent drug users!
answers.feedback: Bob gives you a strange look and makes an excuse to leave shortly after. It seems like your reputation has preceded you. This isnt going to score you any points with the hip New York crowd.

answers.description: Let John smoke it all.
answers.feedback: Shortly after John finishes smoking, he starts to get paranoid. He gets very quiet for a while, only muttering something about The Walrus to himself for the next few hours. After it wears off he still seems a littledifferent.

questions.description: I want to ask the Beatles what they think of Barry Goldwater.

answers.description: PAUL: "Boo!" (shows thumbs down) "I don't like him... I don't like him... unquote!"
answers.feedback: This is a good liberal answer that will motivate sales of your albums.

answers.description: RINGO: Not many people know this but our other idea for a band name was Barrys Boys. We think hes aces.
answers.feedback: This is an answer that will appeal to far right conservatives and not many else.

questions.description: Do you think you'll ever have any appeal for people above the age of twenty?

answers.description: JOHN: "We already have."
answers.feedback: This is a good, witty response that will appeal to the public.

answers.description: PAUL: "Just because you don't like us, you know..."
answers.feedback: This is the perfect comeback to a backhanded question like that.

answers.description: GEORGE: No, but we dont need to. We prefer a younger audience. More willing to join us.
answers.feedback: Join you in what exactly?

questions.description: Sept. 17, 1964: Your next show is in Kansas City. You have room to add one more song to your setlist, which song do you choose?

answers.description: Kansas City / Hey-Hey-Hey-Hey
answers.feedback: Its always fun to play a song named after the city youre in. In this case the classic cover is the perfect song to add to your setlist.

answers.description: If I Fell
answers.feedback: Although I love it, a downtempo song like If I Fell isnt exactly a great song to add to your setlist at this point in the tour.

questions.description: There are rumors that some of your upcoming concerts may be racially segregated, where do you stand on that issue?

answers.description: PAUL: We refuse to play at any segregated show. Whites and blacks both deserve to see The Beatles.
answers.feedback: Good job taking a stand on this issue. Segregation is a hot topic issue but its important to be on the right side of history.

answers.description: RINGO: We may not agree with it, but if a promoter does it we cant stop them.
answers.feedback: Trying to please everyone on an important issue like segregation isnt going to do The Beatles any favours.

questions.description: What do you think of the Dave Clark Five and the Rolling Stones?

answers.description: RINGO: "Well, the Rolling Stones are good."
answers.feedback: Boosting your chief rivals isnt going to help you keep your position as top dog in the American market.

answers.description: JOHN: "We just remarked on that. We like the Stones, you know. Dave Clark's alright, but we prefer the Stones."
answers.feedback: This is a succinct answer that doesnt overly promote the Stones or exclude Dave Clark.

answers.description: PAUL: The Beatles and The Rolling Stones are nothing compared to Dave Clark.
answers.feedback: This answer seems a little out of touch with the youth of America.

questions.description: What are your ambitions?

answers.description: PAUL: "We used to have LOTS of ambitions. You know like, number one records, Sunday Night At The Palladium, Ed Sullivan Show, go to America, you know. We've done an awful lot of them at the moment. We just want to be happy."
answers.feedback: This is a humble answer that makes The Beatles look good to the public.

answers.description: JOHN: Well, we were talking about wanting to open a record label one day. But I think we should buy a plot of land and invite people to live there with us. Imagine that.
answers.feedback: John, what are you talking about? Youve never brought this up to me - your manager!

questions.description: Ringo, It was just three days before you became ill, and I'm wondering... I've heard reports that you may have to go back to the hospital and you may need an operation. I wonder how things are.

answers.description: RINGO: "I'm fine. They just want to take the tonsils out in case they cause any more trouble, you see. There's nothing wrong with them now. But they... you know. It could happen again."
answers.feedback: This is a good answer that should quash any negative rumours about your health for now.

answers.description: RINGO: Well, lets just say The Beatles might just be the Fab Three soon.
answers.feedback: This is the kind of answer that destroys the publics trust in The Beatles' staying power.

answers.description: RINGO: Weve been touring eight days a week, I think once we get back home Ill feel a bit better.
answers.feedback: This is a good answer that disarms a loaded question with a joke.

questions.description: Today is the day youve all been waiting the whole tour for: the day The Beatles meet their hero Elvis Presley! How do you introduce yourselves?

answers.description: Try and get Elvis alone without his manager Colonel Tom.
answers.feedback: Despite your best efforts youre unable to get Elvis alone. Something is very off about his relationship with Colonel Tom. Elvis may not be the king for much longer.

answers.description: Be confrontational, Elvis may be your hero but hes old news.
answers.feedback: Trying to make enemies with the still reigning King of Rock isnt a good idea. It makes you look bad to the public at large.

answers.description: Be polite, you may be star struck but you can try and act normal.
answers.feedback: You have a brief if not awkward conversation with Elvis. Before you know it youre all back in the van on the way to your next show.

questions.description: What are some of your talents? For instance, we know singing, we know music, we know writer, we know photography. What else do you do?

answers.description: JOHN: "I used to paint..."
answers.feedback: The hip young beatniks always admire an artist.

answers.description: GEORGE: "Acrobatics. All sorts of things."
answers.feedback: A non-committal answer like this wont win you points with anyone.

answers.description: RINGO: "Im quite into American politics and history. In fact Im working on designing a board game called The Campaign Trail where you play as political candidates and try to win historical elections."
answers.feedback: Very specific Ringo. Though maybe keep this kind of thing to yourself. People tend to be put off by people like you.

questions.description: Have you heard that your records are getting into the Pop charts in countries all over the world?

answers.description: GEORGE: "Yes. Well, we've heard that our latest record came into the Australian Top Twenty right at Number One, which is very nice. And I think it's selling in other places like that, too."
answers.feedback: This is a good general answer that leaves no one offended.

answers.description: JOHN: Yes. We are most excited that our records charted in Israel.
answers.feedback: This is a very specific answer. Some of the public is weirded out by it.

answers.description: PAUL: We dont really care about charting all over the world. The only place thing that matters to us is that people know us over here in America.
answers.feedback: Appealing to Americas patriotic side is a great idea. Even the beatniks love America.

questions.description: Which artist or musical group do you think has most influenced your music?

answers.description: JOHN: (jokingly) "Nicki Cuff."
answers.feedback: No one in the press junket understands an obscure Liverpool reference like this.

answers.description: PAUL: "Nicki Cuff, I'd say. No, uhh... American colored groups, mainly. And early Elvis Presley."
answers.feedback: Acknowledging The Kings influence on your music is a good idea to appeal to Americans.

questions.description: A psychiatrist in Seattle is saying that you are a menace-- You bring out the destructive instincts in teenagers, and you oughta be banned

answers.description: GEORGE: "Psychiatrists are menaces, too."
answers.feedback: An answer like this will upset everyone for a different reason.

answers.description: JOHN: We are menaces. We want to bring out destructive instincts. The times are changing and you must change with us or get left behind.
answers.feedback: John, please listen to me. You cant say things like this. Youve been acting quite strange recently.

answers.description: PAUL: I dont think music can do that to people, if someone is a destructive person theyre going to find a reason.
answers.feedback: This is a reasonable answer that pacifies a loaded question like that.

questions.description: What influenced you fellas to let your hair grow so long?

answers.description: PAUL: "I think it was my dad, really. He said, 'You know, Paul, it's a bit square,' the haircut I had-- you know, short back and sides. He said, 'Why don't you get a Beatle Cut, son.'"
answers.feedback: This is a humorous answer, something you are all quickly getting known for.

answers.description: GEORGE: Well, you know, we all performed a satanic ritual to gain our musical talents but it came at the cost of our ability to cut our hair.
answers.feedback: Although clearly a joke, it seems some of the more religious members of America now want to boycott The Beatles.

answers.description: JOHN: I think it was mostly the drugs.
answers.feedback: This is an answer that will upset some Americans.

questions.description: You are about to play the final show of the tour. Which song do you close the tour with?

answers.description: Twist and Shout
answers.feedback: This is a classic and rambunctious cover that leaves everyone dancing and sweaty.

answers.description: Scrambled Eggs (WIP Paul song)
answers.feedback: Scrambled eggs, Oh you've got such lovely legs?! This song shouldnt have been played yet. Its too different from your current output and still needs time to cook.

answers.description: A Hard Days Night
answers.feedback: A very thematic closer for the tour, the crowd enjoys it.

questions.description: What do you boys do the night before you head back to England?

answers.description: Try and score some pot to celebrate.
answers.feedback: After the run in with Dylan, you have all started smoking marijuana more. Hopefully this doesnt lead to anything too crazy.

answers.description: Theres no time to celebrate, we have to keep writing.
answers.feedback: You are on a busy schedule and writing as much as you can will help you stay on top.

answers.description: Go out for a drink with Brian and the rest of the crew.
answers.feedback: Making sure to thank the crew and the people that got you here is a good call, and one that makes sure you can tour again in the future.

scenarioDescription:
The year is 1964 and the British Invasion has just began. Dozens of bands from across the pond are starting to break through into the American market.

Chief among these bands are a scrappy group of youngsters from Liverpool named The Beatles. They are now embarking on their first American tour.

Can you take these fab four to the toppermost of the poppermost, or will they be just another footnote in musical history?
